I'd like a viable candidate outside the duopoly. Because both are for big government, no matter what their 'platform' says. Actions are more salient than words.

 
 Personally, I'm for big government. The bigger the beuracracy, the slower things move, which means the longer it takes for anything to get done, which means there's a far greater chance that stupid things will get caught and stopped before they happen. The stupidest things always seem to happen when a bill gets rushed, rather than plodding through the red tape at the usual slow rate.

Dono

I want the best person for the job, be it male, female, black, white, yellow, or something else.

 Most will agree that Jimmy Carter was probably the most decent honorable man to occupy the white house, and that is the main reason he was ineffective in the office. We require lying, cheating, conniving politicos who know how to play the game and herd the sheep.
 Dono
Dono

On another forum, strictly as a joke, I announced that I was running for president. I laid out a brief platform of total nonsense and promised, if elected, to resign as soon as my lifetime benefits were assured and a book deal was made. Imagine my horror when I realized that, despite the obvious fact that I was in no way qualified for the office, I might be a better choice than the major party candidates, Dumb and Dumber. I quickly stopped making any reference to my candidacy and slid quietly into the background. Dumber eked out a victory and here we are. I still feel a tinge of guilt.
 Dono

Most will agree that Jimmy Carter was probably the most decent honorable man to occupy the white house, and that is the main reason he was ineffective in the office. We require lying, cheating, conniving politicos who know how to play the game and herd the sheep.
 Dono

 
 Decent and honorable okay, but I think his ineffectiveness stemmed more from overthinking all problems, and not from us being unable to handle those virtues in a president. For instance, his speech that correctly identified the problem with America being "malaise". This idea came from an intense fact-finding session he convened at Camp David with the heavy thinkers of the day. The problem was that he identified the problem but offered no solution, a terribly stupid blunder. 
 
 All Reagan had to do was offer a message of hope. We must remember our substantial presidents have had those simple messages.
georged

All Reagan had to do was offer a message of hope. We must remember our substantial presidents have had those simple messages.

 
 Let's not drag out what the recent 'substantial' presidents have cost this country. That depresses all hope.

Personally, I'm for big government. The bigger the beuracracy, the slower things move, which means the longer it takes for anything to get done, which means there's a far greater chance that stupid things will get caught and stopped before they happen. The stupidest things always seem to happen when a bill gets rushed, rather than plodding through the red tape at the usual slow rate.

 
 Though the bad thing about that is that it slows down the smartest things too.
Dono

As I recall, your primary campaign plank was to get the book deal advance and do some first class traveling in AF 1?

 I also promised to flood the white house lawn so that visiting constituents in 4-wheel drive trucks would have a place to play when visiting, and I pledged a 10% discount on nightly rental of the Lincoln bedroom to any one driving a truck. I also suggested that we invade Tahiti. Instead of bombs, we could drop money, which would eliminate the problem of rebuilding and have the same effect on our deficit. This would also stimulate our lagging recruitment efforts. Too bad, I would have looked good on Rushmore (speaking of looking good, John Bolton, the new U.N. rep that Bush just slipped past congress looks a LOT like me).
 Dono
snakespit

I won't comment on the current of recent former presidents, although if Ronnie Reagan was alive and running for president I would vote for him in a heartbeat (actually the only presidential candidate I would have voted for since I have been alive if I had been old enough at the time) 
 
 I do think it is time to look past the 2 party system. I think that there are plenty of candidates out there who don't get the publicity or exposure that could carry thier message to the people, therefore they are never given a serious shot at becoming president. Our media and the demopublicans make sure that the 2 party system is the only game in town. We don't have the luxery in this country of picking a president based on who we think will do the most good, we are forced to pick our president on who we think will screw the country up the least. I think the other large problem is that too many americans are afraid to step out of line and vote for a 3rd party candidate. I heard it over and over the last election, when people were asked about the 3rd party candidates, they would simply state that since they did not have a reasonable chance to win, they did not want to waste their vote on them.
billsco

It's too bad people have the idea that third party candidates are a 'wasted vote'.
 
 As to the OP, my early pick will be McCain. He won't get the GOP nod, but I doubt I'll still be a Republican by then.
georged

but I doubt I'll still be a Republican by then.

 
 A strange transformation that as a former staunch Republican I've gone through over the past few years. Other than social morality I can no longer determine any difference between Democrat or Republican ideology. Republicans are now spending more public funds we don't have and expanding government at a rate Democrats never approached.
